snippet: The Nobel laureate Peter Higgs, 85, whose public appearances have been as rare and fleeting as the tracks of the Higgs boson, discussed his life’s work in an interview at an Edinburgh cafe.
abstract: Dennis Overbye Out There column profiles Dr Peter Higgs, 85-year-old physicist who first theorized existence of new particle that would explain how other particles get mass in 1964; Higgs, who won 2013 Nobel Prize in Physics for discovery, is in many ways as elusive as particle he helped uncover.
lead_paragraph: The Nobel laureate Peter Higgs, 85, whose public appearances have been as rare and fleeting as the tracks of the Higgs boson, discussed his life’s work in an interview at an Edinburgh cafe.

headline.print_headline: A Pioneer as Elusive as His Particle
headline.main: A Pioneer as Elusive as His Particle
